title: The Film Critic No One Asked For ft. Imran Khan
description:
The best tongue twister award goes to the lovely people I met at Tamnay’s workshop and in this episode of Unfiltered by Samdish, I impart that wisdom to the self-confessed movie geek, Imran Khan. 

From obsessing over films and storytelling to reflecting on life away from the public eye, from past work experiences to upcoming projects, from never actively chasing money to the overwhelming feeling of having enough, from hating the birthday attention to loving his Filmfare hosting experience, Imran talks about what it means to step back, slow down, and return on his own terms.

The conversation also weaves through his fascinating family tree, a bag of all sorts of people and how that mix shaped who he is today.

Thoughtful, nerdy, and refreshingly honest. 

Here’s presenting, The Film Critic No One Asked For ft. Imran Khan

title: One CM At A Time (If You Know, You Know) - Sorry Conrad
description:
For this episode, I travelled all the way to Shillong to meet the Chief Minister of Meghalaya, Conrad Sangma.

Very much a Delhi boy, raised in the power corridors of Lutyens’ Delhi, Sangma today leads one of the largest political parties in the North-East, an inheritance from his father, but a legacy he is carving out in his own way.

Against the stunning backdrop of Shillong, Sangma spoke candidly about his political journey, his CM duties, his failures, and why he couldn’t inherit his wife’s property (???).

Between laughs, jokes, and the occasional roast, the discussion also spanned to corruption in the North-Eastern states, rat-hole mining in Meghalaya, and his relationship with the BJP.

And finally, the toughest question of all: is Conrad Sangma the coolest Chief Minister in India? You’ll find out by the end of this video.

Watch, One CM At A Time (If You Know, You Know)

Come, spend this day with us. You’ll see why we can’t stay away from Bihar for too long.

title: Is This The Deadliest Secret of Our Country? | Inside India's Worst Health Crisis
description:
For most, working is a way to survive, but for the mine workers of Karauli, Rajasthan, it has become a slow and painful path to death. This region’s economy heavily depends on stone mining and quarrying, industries that expose workers to deadly silica dust, leading to the incurable disease: Silicosis.

To uncover the reality behind these numbers, the Unfiltered team traveled to Karauli. What we witnessed was far worse than anything we could have anticipated. These workers, bound by poverty and desperation, survive on painkillers just to endure another day of relentless labour. With little compensation, limited awareness, and no alternate livelihood, they are trapped in a vicious cycle, where survival itself is paid for with their health, and eventually, their lives.

Here’s presenting the unfiltered truth of this deadly industry through Bharat Ek Khoj: India's Worst Health Crisis | Unfiltered by Samdish

title: What Does an Indian Port Look Like? | Inside One of India’s Oldest Ports
description:
“The wind may turn back — but a Kharva never does.”

Welcome to the new episode of Bharat EK Khoj. This time, Captain Samdish Bhatia sails 1300 km away from Delhi to the wild, roaring edge of the Arabian Sea — Vanakbara Port in Diu.
Vanakbara is home to a community of fishermen, or Kharvas, who spend 8 out of 12 months sailing the sea, chasing fish and a living. 

We spent days capturing their lives in this cinematic episode. From Thandel Ramesh, a senior captain, to the young Khalasis learning the ropes and telling their stories of resilience and camaraderie.

How do they catch and store fish? How dangerous is the sea? How do they prepare for their trips, and do they even make any money? 

Are you ready for this cinematic voyage? Presenting: India's Most Ignored Island | Bharat Ek Khoj | Unfiltered by Samdish

title: OMG: Ye Bhi Mera India?  Inside the Extraordinary African Village of Gujarat
description:
While the Unfiltered team was travelling for a shoot in Gujarat, we were reminded of a small village in the Gir Somnath district, where an African community resides from hundreds of years. It's considered to be a tourist spot because of the absurd nature of finding a clan as theirs in a remote area of an Indian State. But to our surprise, we discovered that these communities have far more to offer than just a tourist attraction — there’s a depth that goes beyond what meets the eye.

Officially known as the Siddi community, these people refer to one another as badshah, meaning 'king', and it’s not just a title...It's a reflection of their attitude towards life. With an infectious zest, they embrace each day to the fullest with whatever they have and make it all seem to look fun by dancing through life (quite literally, I have to say). 

In our never ending journey of exploring the much overlooked parts of the country. Here's a documentation that will make you say, OMG: Ye Bhi Mera India? Inside the extraordinary Siddis of Gujarat

title: Indian Workers Kidnapped in Africa
description:
Namaskar doston,

Haan, hame pata hai ki kaafi waqt ho gaya video aaye hue. Aur is beech, kaafi kuch ho gaya.

Kaafi kuch, jo sabne dekha...aur kuch aisa bhi, jo hamari nigaahon se chhoot gaya. Usi doosri category ki ek prastuti lekar, we’re back. A story about five Indian migrant workers who had left their homeland in search of a livelihood abroad, and now their safety is uncertain and their whereabouts, unknown.

On April 25, five workers from Jharkhand’s Giridih district were abducted by armed gunmen in the conflict-hit Tillabéri region of Niger, West Africa. They’re still missing. We decided to head to Giridih to speak to their families caught in grief, confusion, and painful uncertainty. Will this video change anything in the grand scheme of things?  We don’t know. But it’s an attempt to make you more aware of the situation of your fellow citizens. Unn 5 logon ke baare mein, jo is 1.4 billion ke jhund se bichhad chuke hain, aur ek anjaane desh mein lapata hain.

Presenting, Inside Jharkhand's Troubling Truth

title: Manipur’s Shocking Reality, My Crazy Experience Inside the Conflict
description:
The violence that started on 3rd May 2023, between the Meitei and Kuki-Zo communities, triggered by disputes over Scheduled Tribe status and fears of resource dominance, has culminated into a full-fledged ethnic/civil conflict. This has claimed hundreds of lives, displaced over 60,000 people, and left families shattered.

We ventured into the relief camps on both sides, seeking to capture the unspoken anguish etched into the lives of those who endured.

To say that our experience in Manipur shook us to the core and that the sheer apathy, if not complicity of the state, has left Manipur fully divided would be a gross understatement.

It remains a real-life example of what happens when 2 identities decide to fight, when the idea of India as envisioned by our founders is perhaps ruined beyond repair, when the mind is with fear and no head dare be held high, when narrow domestic walls are erected and manipulated to break the world into tiny fragments.

It was, and remains a reminder of what happens when we decide to fight, when we choose to hate. 

Presenting My Manipur Experience | Bharat Ek Khoj | Unfiltered by Samdish

title: I Went Off the Grid for 24 Hours With Kashmir’s Shepherds – Here’s the Shocking Reality
description:
While the rest of Kashmir is bustling with election slogans & rally traffic, life in this part of the valley seems unchanged. In an endeavour to explore the hidden corners of India, I landed up in the silent & serene mountain ranges of the Budgam district that serve as a humble abode to the shepherds of the area. This community of Shepherds get settled in their temporary homes, also known as a Doke, for 6 months along with their livestock to complete the grazing period.

The scenic views and the lush green grass are a treat to one's eyes but what lies behind all of it are the everyday struggles faced by the people of this region. They talk to me about how they have no road connectivity to shops, schools, or even hospitals. Water & electricity are a privilege and employment is nowhere to be found.

The only thing they demand from the government is 'tourism'. In the hope that tourism will, by default, provide them with employment, opportunities and basic necessities. Watch & experience the unknown world of Kunazabal in Jammu & Kashmir.

title: I Time Travelled To This 18th Century Village in Bihar | Bharat Ek Khoj Ep18 | Unfiltered by Samdish
description:
In an endeavour to explore the secluded landscapes of our country, I travelled to the Southern ends of Bihar where I interacted with the Mahadalit community of Durgapur in district Bodh Gaya. From extreme poverty & illiteracy to a concerning amount of malnourishment, this village lacks basic human integrity, let alone being a 'developed society'. While highlighting the caste discrimination in the area, the villagers talked about how no government has ever paid attention to their living conditions and they have always been left behind when it comes to providing them with basic facilities like schools & hospitals. 

A day in this village felt like a time travel to the medieval era where everything depended on the caste ladder. People here do not receive electricity but are paying heavy bills, managing three meals a day is a daily struggle & when getting work is hard, begging is their only option. 

Watch & Experience as we shift the focus from the touristy side to the harsh realities of Bodh Gaya. 

Presenting, I Time Travelled To This 18th Century Village in Bihar | Bharat Ek Khoj Ep18 | Unfiltered by Samdish

title: I Went Inside Uttar Pradesh's District Where Voters Were Denied the Right to Vote | Samdish Bhatia
description:
Voters in at least four villages in Uttar Pradesh’s Sambhal district have accused the state police of confiscating identity cards and lathi-charging, thereby not letting people exercise their right to vote. The episode took place during the third phase of the Lok Sabha elections on May 7. Incidentally, all of these villages happen to be Muslim-dominated.

I went to Obri, one of the villages where voting was stalled due to alleged violence at the polling station, and spoke to the residents about what unfolded on the polling day.

title: I Investigated the Cancer District of Uttar Pradesh | Bharat Ek Khoj Ep17 | Unfiltered by Samdish
description:
Water is one of the basic factors of human survival but in the Baghpat District of western Uttar Pradesh, water has become the reason for death. People in this region have been living under a web of diseases caused by the contaminated groundwater they consume daily.

In an attempt to understand the severity of the situation, we went to one of the gravely affected villages of Baghpat called Gangnauli. Whether a person is 10 years old or 50, illnesses like Stomach infections, Bone deformities and Cancer have affected every second person in this village. From requesting clean drinking water to fighting a court case for it...the villagers have tried it all.

title: A Day Inside the Farmers' Protest 2024 | Unfiltered by Samdish
description:
On 13th February, Farmers from Punjab began their "Delhi Chalo" march to press for their longstanding demands that include a legal guarantee for purchasing crops at Minimum Support Price (MSP) and a farm loan waiver.

Their protest march was halted by police forces at Shambhu and Khanauri border points on the Haryana-Punjab border. description:
Agariyas are a community of salt farmers found in the Little Rann of Kutch in Gujarat. They move from their respective villages to the desert for eight months to farm salt in harsh weather conditions.

title: Gaddi | Bharat Ek Khoj Episode 5 | The Shepherds Of Himachal Pradesh ft. Samdish Bhatia
description:
The Gaddis are a semi-agricultural and a semi-pastoral tribe, predominantly found in Himachal Pradesh. They are shepherds who travel long distances and across various terrains to graze their livestock.

title: Bharat Ek Khoj Episode 3 | Inside A Village In Uttar Pradesh : Chandauli
description:
About 60 kilometres from the city of Varanasi, lies a village called Mubarakpur in the Chandauli district of Uttar Pradesh. I spent a day with the people of Mubarakpur, spoke to the children, youth, and the elderly to understand their lifestyle, livelihood, and their relationship with the state. While politics and promises have reached the village, policies catering to the betterment of its residents are nowhere to be found. This film, Inside A Village In Chandauli, Uttar Pradesh is our attempt at highlighting the reality of Mubarakpur, which we hope can make things better for our co-citizens who call it their home.
